docs.snippet: An  article  last Saturday about Apple's victory in a patent lawsuit against Samsung described incorrectly one Apple patent that was at issue. The patent covers a method of distinguishing between one-fingered scrolling on a touch-screen device and...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Saturday about Apple's victory in a patent lawsuit against Samsung described incorrectly one Apple patent that was at issue. The patent covers a method of distinguishing between one-fingered scrolling on a touch-screen device and two-fingered gestures like pinching to zoom out of an image. It does not cover the pinch-to-zoom feature itself. The error was repeated in an article on Monday about the case's effect on innovations in technology and it appeared again on Tuesday in an article about the possibility the decision could move Apple closer to a fight with Google.

headline.main: Corrections

headline.seo: Walden Pond, Thoreau’s Retreat in Concord, Is Often Hard to Find
headline.main: Where’s Walden? GPS Often Doesn’t Know
headline.print_headline: Where’s Walden? GPS Often Doesn’t Know

docs.abstract: Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreau’s idyllic retreat in the woods of Concord, Mass, remains hard to find, despite 21st-century navigational conveniences; Google maps and some GPS devices have been leading a number of travelers to the wrong Walden: an identically named reservoir, next to a golf course, in Lynn.

docs.snippet: For companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft that sell cloud computing services, the most drastic changes may be in places most of us do not see. Already, places without clean water, decent sanitation or steady electricity are using supercomput...
docs.lead_paragraph: For companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft that sell cloud computing services, the most drastic changes may be in places most of us do not see. Already, places without clean water, decent sanitation or steady electricity are using supercomputers. Cheki is a used-car classifieds business that serves about a million people a month, mostly in Kenya and Nigeria. Most of the one million people using the site are looking at it with Android -based smartphones that cost about $70, according to Thomas Shaw, the company's information technology manager. Imagine things in a few years, when Huawei, which makes most of the devices, gets those phone prices even lower.

headline.main: Cloud Helps Change Emerging Economies

docs.abstract: Bits blog; cloud computing services are helping change emerging markets in several developing countries. (M)1

docs.snippet: An  article  on Monday about the free-speech advocacy of Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter's top lawyer, misstated the response of Google, another technology company wrestling globally with the concept of free expression, to the theft in China of pr...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the free-speech advocacy of Alexander Macgillivray, Twitter's top lawyer, misstated the response of Google, another technology company wrestling globally with the concept of free expression, to the theft in China of proprietary code that was used to hack into Gmail accounts of human rights activists. Google redirected Chinese-language search requests to its Hong Kong site after the 2010 hacking; it did not withdraw from China. (Engineering, advertising and other operations remain there.) The article also misstated the frequency of Google's and Twitter's release of data about government requests. The data is published twice a year, not annually.

headline.main: Corrections

docs.snippet: The smartphones going into the world's next two billion pairs of hands may not belong to either Google or Apple, but to Mozilla.   The Mozilla Foundation, which oversees open source software projects like the Firefox Web browser, expects to releas...
docs.lead_paragraph: The smartphones going into the world's next two billion pairs of hands may not belong to either Google or Apple, but to Mozilla. The Mozilla Foundation, which oversees open source software projects like the Firefox Web browser, expects to release a mobile operating system for smartphones early next year. Its target market is Latin America, then the rest of the developing world, where smartphones from Apple and Google are still too expensive for most people.

headline.main: Technology News: Mozilla Plans a Smartphone Operating System

docs.abstract: Mozilla Foundation, which oversees open-source software projects like the Firefox Web browser, expects to release a mobile operating system for smartphones early in 2013. Photo (M)

headline.seo: For Kansas City, Google Internet Drive Becomes Civic Cause
headline.main: In One City, Signing Up for Internet Becomes a Civic Cause
headline.print_headline: Signing Up For Internet Becomes Civic Cause

docs.abstract: Racial divides in Kansas City, Mo, have become inflamed due to the implementation of Google Fiber, project that would wire homes and institutions in the city with nation's fastest Internet connection; Google announced that only areas where enough residents preregistered and paid a deposit would get the service, and many black communities lagged in the registration process.

docs.snippet: The city does not codify neighborhood boundaries, but unsung arbiters are using sites like Google Maps and Wikipedia to draw lines between, say, Park Slope and Gowanus in Brooklyn....

headline.seo: Amateur Mapmakers Reshape New York Neighborhoods Online
headline.main: Amateur Mapmakers Redraw Boundaries, Working Online
headline.print_headline: Amateur Mapmakers Redraw Boundaries, Working Online

docs.abstract: New York City does not codify its neighborhood boundaries, leaving profit-hungry real estate brokers and civic leaders to fight it out; now dozens of amateur mapmakers are reshaping the lines themselves, using Web sites like Google Maps and Wikipedia to provide their own definitions for where neighborhoods begin and end.

docs.abstract: Google and Amazon.com are waging war behind the scenes to become the pre-eminent online mall, and e-commerce sites large and small are being affected; Google is inching into e-commerce, and charging retailers to appear on its site, move it says will improve product listings; product searches on Amazon have grown 73 percent over the last year.

headline.seo: Google Blocks Inflammatory Video in Egypt and Libya
headline.main: As Violence Spreads in Arab World, Google Blocks Access to Inflammatory Video
headline.print_headline: As Violence Spreads in Arab World, Google Blocks Access to Inflammatory Video

docs.abstract: Google, owner of YouTube, blocks access in Egypt and Libya to video that has incited violence across the Arab world; action is unusual, since the video does not violate the company's terms of service, and brings up questions about freedom of expression and censorship.

headline.main: On Web, a Fine Line on Free Speech Across the Globe
headline.print_headline: On Web, a Fine Line on Free Speech Across the Globe

docs.abstract: Google's fine parsing over its anti-Islamic video that provoked violence worldwide has led to a debate in the blogosphere about whether the video constituted hateful or offensive speech; as Web companies set their own rules about what kind of expression is allowed, legal experts say they must be flexible to strike the right balance between democratic values and law.

headline.main: Daily Report: Google Fills in the Blank, and a German Cries Foul

headline.main: As Google Fills In Blank, a German Cries Foul
headline.print_headline: As Google Fills In Blank, A German Cries Foul

docs.abstract: Bettina Wulff, wife of former German Pres Christian Wulff, files a lawsuit against Google over autocomplete suggestions that appear when her name is typed into the search engine; some of the suggested phrases that appear relate to rumors, begun in 2006, that Wulff once worked as an escort.

docs.abstract: Millions of iPhone customers may soon find themselves losing touch with an old friend: Google's maps. As Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report in Thursday's New York Times, Apple released a software update for the iPhone that, among other changes, replaces the Google maps that have been on the phone since 2007 with Apple's own maps.

docs.abstract: Apple releases iOS 6, software update for the iPhone that replaces Google maps that have been on the phone since 2007; reviewers criticize the new Apple Maps app, saying it botches simple searches and does not come with information about public transportation; app includes some features that were not in the old version.

headline.main: Has Apple Peaked?
headline.print_headline: Has Apple Peaked?

docs.abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column contends major flaws in Apple's iPhone 5, like substituting Google maps with its own inferior mapping system, show that Apple has become too successful a company to continue developing innovative products; says it is the nature of capitalism that big companies become defensive while newer rivals emerge with better, smarter ideas.

docs.snippet: The top antitrust regulator for the European Union said there were limits to how much longer his office would try to negotiate a settlement with Google over its Internet search engine....

headline.main: Europe Hints at Impatience in Settling Google Case
headline.print_headline: Europe Hints At Impatience In Settling Google Case

docs.abstract: Joaquin Almunia, European Union's top antitrust regulator, signals that there are limits to how much longer his office would try to negotiate a settlement with Google over whether its Internet search engine favored the company’s own Web offerings to the detriment of competitors; warns that he retains the power to issue formal charges if negotiations do not soon bear fruit.

headline.print_headline: IPhone 5 Fever? Don’t Count Samsung Out

docs.snippet: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube....
docs.lead_paragraph: Once the best of friends, Google and Apple are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube.

headline.seo: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on the iPhone
headline.main: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt on iPhone
headline.print_headline: Apple’s Feud With Google Is Now Felt On iPhone

docs.abstract: Google and Apple, once close allies, are battling in courtrooms and in the consumer marketplace, with iPhone users in the cross-fire after Apple removed Google’s maps app and YouTube; disappearing apps show just how far-reaching the companies' rivalry has become, as well as the importance of mobile users to their businesses.

byline.contributor: Brian X. Chen contributed reporting from New York.

docs.snippet: Google is developing a maps application for the iPhone and the iPad that it is seeking to finish by the end of the year, according to people involved with the effort....

headline.main: Google Working on Maps for iPhone and iPad

docs.abstract: Google is developing a maps application for the iPhone and the iPad that it is seeking to finish by the end of the year, according to people involved with the effort.

byline.original: By NICK WINGFIELD and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

docs.snippet: Google said it hasn't made a move to restore its maps to the iPhone, but it declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apple's App Store. And why would Google show its cards? Here is an opportunity for the company to show ...

headline.main: Apple's Competitors Pile On With Map Critiques

docs.abstract: Google said it hasn't made a move to restore its maps to the iPhone, but it declined to say whether the company had submitted a new maps app to Apple's App Store. And why would Google show its cards? Here is an opportunity for the company to show that phones using Android have a more robust maps product. Some of Apple's other competitors are already playing this game.

docs.snippet: California became the third state to explicitly legalize cars that drive themselves. Google, which is building the cars and has been heavily lobbying lawmakers, says they are safer because they reduce human error....

headline.main: With a Push From Google, California Legalizes Driverless Cars
headline.print_headline: Driverless Cars Get Official O.K.

docs.abstract: California became the third state to explicitly legalize cars that drive themselves. Google, which is building the cars and has been heavily lobbying lawmakers, says they are safer because they reduce human error.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Google Oceans, and Promises 'The Jetsons' Made Us

docs.abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Wednesday's selection includes a report that says few sales can be traced to social media, a cheaper way to charge an iPhone 5 and an argument that Apple must change its strategy when it comes to television.

headline.main: Top Google Executive in Brazil Faces Arrest Over Video
headline.print_headline: Top Google Executive in Brazil Faces Arrest Over Video

docs.abstract: Elections court in Brazil orders the arrest of Fabio Jose Silva Coelho, Google's top executive in the country, after the company failed to take down YouTube videos attacking a local mayoral candidate.

docs.snippet: Authorities questioned Google’s senior executive in Brazil on Wednesday over a YouTube video that criticized a local mayoral candidate, and a court ruled that YouTube must block the video....

headline.main: Authorities Question Head of Google in Brazil Over Video

docs.abstract: Authorities questioned Google’s senior executive in Brazil on Wednesday over a YouTube video that criticized a local mayoral candidate, and a court ruled that YouTube must block the video.

headline.seo: Apple’s New Maps App Is Upgraded, but Full of Snags - Review
headline.main: A Map App, as Sleek as iPhone 5, Is Often Off
headline.print_headline: A Map App, As Sleek As iPhone 5, Is Often Off

docs.abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Apple's replacement of Google’s maps with its own, inferior mapping system, built from scratch; notes in new iPhone app entire locations have been mislabeled or erased; contends making the app reliable and complete will take a very long time.

docs.snippet: Complaints and jokes about Apple’s new maps have not stopped since the company released iOS 6 last week, a software update that replaced Google’s maps with its own....

headline.main: Tim Cook Apologizes for Apple's Maps

docs.abstract: Complaints and jokes about Apple’s new maps have not stopped since the company released iOS 6 last week, a software update that replaced Google’s maps with its own.

docs.snippet: The problems with Apple’s new mobile maps were embarrassing, but the company has a tendency to bungle services that rely heavily on the Internet....
docs.lead_paragraph: The problems with Apple’s new mobile maps were embarrassing, but the company has a tendency to bungle services that rely heavily on the Internet.

headline.main: Apple Apologizes for Misstep on Maps
headline.print_headline: Apple Apologizes for Misstep on Maps

docs.abstract: Apple apologizes to iPhone customers for its new mobile maps, which often direct users to nonsensical routes and misplaced landmarks; remarkably suggests users try map services from rivals like Microsoft and Google while it works on fixes; incident shows users' reliance on map services and highlights Apple's tendency to bungle services that rely heavily on the Internet.

byline.original: By NICK WINGFIELD and BRIAN X. CHEN
